channel.title: New sound design im working on
channel.description:
so i pretty much picked up Electronic music when i was about 9 or 10 and i was never satisfied with the modern pop music around that time 5 years on ive used synths to create new sounds mainlt including basses and other sound effects. unfortunately after my computer broke 1 year ago (and still havent gotten a new one) i have been stuck in one place. thats when i found Auxy of July last year. i got to grips with various instruments and after the automation update i have really gotten to grips with making similar sounding or new sounding sound design. a track im working on heavily focuses on using these techniques and i encourage everyone else to go out of their comfort zone and try something new. i havent heard these techniques used in anyone else tracks yet and i think that everyone else can try to.
the most popular theme right now is seemingly future bass but id like to see a lor more diverse genres, my favourite being neuro bass which i myself like to think i create.
anyway i just want to see more variety and interesting sounds in tracks today. if anyone knows anyone like this then let me know ;}
~X

item.source: New sound design im working on

item.title: New sound design im working on
item.dc:creator: Twizard
item.description:
UPDATE

I’ve experimented a lot, and someone helped me out too. But, there are ways to make Neuro basses.
Since a few weeks ago my dnb style completely changed because Hexx found out a way to make Reese/Neuro basses, by using sweet spring, pitch all the way down, and bitcrusher, also some chorus.
I like to layer it with sweet saw and mix it the exact way as I do with sweet spring.
Needy can be a very good second Neuro bass, so for example the first 2 bars sweet spring and saw, and the third and fourth needy, with pitch to make it interesting.
I’ll try to find more neuro basses so more updates might be coming

Read full topic

item.title: New sound design im working on
item.dc:creator: Xiejra
item.description:
Back when I used Auxy, My go too “gritty” basses where mainly Racer, beam, Lobster puma and a couple others I think. Best example(s) of where I used these are probably in my tracks Berries: https://soundcloud.com/xiejramusic/berries and false face:https://soundcloud.com/xiejramusic/false-face
(Shamless plug but for educational purposes)

Read full topic
item.source: New sound design im working on

item.title: New sound design im working on
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Xiejra:

Also slight highpassing the sound

100% agreed, I definitely do this as well (never passing about 25% highpass). It doesn’t need a lot, subtle is very good here.

Read full topic
item.source: New sound design im working on

item.title: New sound design im working on
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
I was gonna @ Xiejra haha, but didn’t wanna be bothersome. The stuff I’ve heard him do is quite similar to what you’re looking for.

SeamlessR is a pretty cool guy to watch stuff from, this video actually shows a pretty smart way of doing this, that you could do in Auxy. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eVWPIJrLmVg

The biggest problem though is that if you are gonna split the one sound into four different frequency spectra, you’re gonna use up four different instrument slots… so that’s a bummer. But the way he does his here could totally work in Auxy.

Read full topic

item.title: New sound design im working on
item.dc:creator: Xiejra
item.description:
yes. ive found many instruments that sound very interesting when pushed incredibly low. my favourites being Puma and Lobster in “The future”. resembles some what of a SNAILS reese. when automating pitch and highpass filter you can get Growl sounds too
